div.sent: There are more than 45 ethnic groups living in Bangladesh.
Each of the ethnic groups maintains its own culture and traditions.
These small groups of people are known as Adivasis.
They live in the hills, forests and plain lands.
We will now know about the life-styles of some of the Adivasis.
The Chakmas in their own language call themselves ‘Chagma’.
Chakmas live in the Rangamati and Khagrachhari districts.
Scatterdly they also live in the Bandarban district.
Chakmas are Buddists.
They are divided in many tribes.
They help one another in times of danger and financial need.
They have certain social characteristics.
We will now know about them.
The chakmas call their villages Adam and the village chief Karbari.
The villages are located in open spaces on low hills beside small rivers.
They build platforms with wood and bamboo on strong trees for living.
They use wooden stairs to get to the platforms.
They call it ijar.
There are temples in almost all the villages.
A temple is called kang in their language.
Now-a-days chakmas live in the plain lands also.
They have earned good names in education, business and trades as well as in jobs.
The staple food of the chakmas is rice.
They like to eat fish, meat and vegetable with rice.
They are very fond of dry fish.
The chakmas weave fabric in their own looms.
They make their clothes with this fabric.
Their indigenous tradition is imprinted in these clothes.
The name of the traditional dress chakma women wear is called pinon khadi.
The boys wear different kinds of dresses.
Now the chakmas have become used to wearing modern dresses.
Chakmas follow Jum method in cultivating their lands.
This method of cultivation is called Jum.
They plough the lands and grow various crops.
They make dresses.
Shawls and other products made by them have great demand home and abroad.
They make baskets, fans, combs, flutes and other musical instruments from bamboos and canes.
The baskets made by them are very nice.
Chakrnas observe various religious and social occasions.
Besides this, during celebrating Maghi Purnima they observe kathin chibar danotsav.
Biju is their greatest festival.
Chakmas observe many rituals and hold various functions.
After birth children are fed honey.
After seven days a priest is called to purify the infant by washing its hair.
They bury the children after death.
Customs followed in marriages are very nice.
When the bridegroom's party reach the bride's house they are received very cordially.
With this the marriage ceremony comes to an end.
The Chakmas have their own alphabet and language.
They talk in their language among themselves.
They have their own songs, dances and literature.
Fairy tales, legends and nursery rhymes also are prevalent among them.
Girls like to play bauchi.
Chakmas enjoy good health.
They are studying in Bangla.
Recently opportunity has been created for them to study in their own language.
They are very much careful about their own language and culture.
Most of the Marmas live in Bandarban, Khagrachhari and Rangamati districts.
Marmas also live in Cox's bazaar, Patuakhali and Barguna districts.
In these areas they are known as Rakhain.
Marma society is patriarchal.
They have their own king.
The king conducts the social cases with the help of aides.
Marmas are divided in a few tribes.
A few villages make a Mouja.
The chief of Mouja is called headman.
The chief of the village is called Roaja or Karbari.
The district administrator appoints the headmen at the recommendation of the king.
Mannas live a well-disciplined life in the society.
They love songs, dances and merriments.
Marma society is also full of various occasions.
We will now know about them.
The staple food of the Marmas is rice.
They like to eat fish, meat and vegetable.
They are fond of curries prepared with hen, chicken and dry fish.
In earlier days Marma men used to wear handloom-woven clothes named doah.
Now-a-days they wear lungis and shirts.
Girls like to adorn themselves.
They make different kinds of attractive chignons.
They also wear Arakani dresses.
They use waist band called khagro made of silver.
The marmas are very hard-working.
They follow Jum method in cultivation.
The women do the household chores as well as take part in cultivation.
In groups they prey on fish and crabs in the rivers.
They make clothes and cigars.
Like the Ckakmas, Marmas are also Buddhists.
Both young boys and girls take part in religious and social functions.
The main social festival of the Marmas is called sangai.
During religious festivals they go to Kang to pay their homage to Gautam Buddha.
After birth a child is named on an auspicious day.
An astrologer (Boidya) is invited to select a name.
Marma boys cannot marry anyone outside their tribes.
But the girls are allowed to marry somebody outside the tribes.
In Marma society the girls usually choose their bridegrooms.
A marriage ceremony is held with great pomp and fun-fair.
This worship ceremony is known as chung-mangleh.
Now-a-days Marmas are educating themselves.
They are studying in schools, colleges and universities.
Besides, they are doing jobs and business.
The Saontals live in the regions of Dinajpur and Rangpur.
The Saontals live in great numbers in Ghoraghat.
Fulbari, Chirirbandar, Kaharol of Dinajpur district and in Pirganj of Rangpur district.
A small number of Saontals also live in Rajshahi and Bogura regions.
The Saontals have been living in this country since ancient times.
They are divided in twelve tribes.
In Saontal language these tribes are called Paaris.
The houses are small and made of mud.
There is no window in the house.
The Saontals like to live clean and tidy.
Saontal men used to wear dhuti made with white linen.
Now they wear lungi, dhuti, genji and gamchha.
Women wear a dress divided in two parts named fata.
Now they also wear saris.
All male folks have ulki imprinted in their hands.
Women use ornaments like bala, jhumka, ring, mal, hasuli, etc, made of silver.
Saontal women like to adorn their chignons (kliopa) with flowers.
Before they used to follow the ritual of cremating the dead body.
At present for financial reasons Saontals everywhere in Bangladesh bury the dead.
Rice is the staple food of the saontals.
They are very much fond offish, crabs, hens, chickens, pigs, birds and rabbits.
The saontals have accepted agriculture as their main occupation from ancient times.
Both men and women work in the fields.
Men plough the land and women sow the seeds and reap the crops.
Saontals make the agricultural tools by themselves.
They are very much enthusiastic about hunting.
Now they are facing problems in this occupation as the forests are reducing.
Presently many Saontal men and women work as porters, labourers, workers and others.
In Saontal language gods are called bonga.
The sun is their chief god.
The god of the hills is called marangmuro.
This god has the maximum influence on the lives of the Saontals.
They believe this god to be responsible for their life and death.
The name of their home god is boncher.
Saontals are very fond of amusement.
During various religious and social functions they indulge themselves in songs and dances.
They have close relation with nature.
They arrange various festivals.
Their annual festival is called sohrai.
In this festival girls dance in groups.
They celebrate baha festival when flowers blossom at the end of winter.
The name of one of their favourite festival is dasai.
They follow their own social Icustoms.
They lead a very simple life.
At present Saontals are being influenced by bengali culture.
Many of them are becoming used to modern life-style after receiving education.
Changes are observed in their behavior and practices.
They are interested in arts and crafts.
They make and play on musical instruments like dhol, dotara, flute, mego.
They draw pictures on the walls of their houses.
They draw designs on pots and pitchers by lime.
All of us will live in this country together.
Adivasis are also citizens of Bangladesh.
We will be respectful towards their social rites and customs.
In this way a friendly relationship will grow up among all of us.
